list-item.p: Among young children with solo-infections of influenza viruses, adenoviruses, and RSV, the overall viral–bacterial codetection rate was 60%. The most frequently codetected bacteria were H influenzae in adenoviral infection (46.2%), M catarrhalis in RSV infection (34.2%), and S pneumoniae in influenza (50.0%; 5/10). Although the presence of viral–bacterial coinfection was not a risk factor for severe LRTIs, the codetection of H influenzae was the protective factor for wheezing, and pneumococcal codetection was associated with reduced severity of viral LRTIs.
